item.title: Premier Steven Marshall pushes for Adelaide to become national space agency headquarters - The Advertiser
item.description:
Premier Steven Marshall pushes for Adelaide to become national space agency headquarters  The Advertiser

Premier Steven Marshall is pushing for Adelaide to become the Houston-like mission control of the nations space agency ahead of an announcement as soon ...

item.title: Former SA premier Jay Weatherill to retire from politics - ABC News
item.description:
Former SA premier Jay Weatherill to retire from politics  ABC News

Former South Australian premier Jay Weatherill has announced he will be stepping away from the limelight after 16 years in the state's Parliament.

item.title: Video - The Australian
item.description:
Video  The Australian

Former South Australian premier Jay Weatherill has announced his retirement from state politics after serving 16 years in the sector. Mr Weatherill led the state ...

item.title: Tributes for late, respected businessman Tony Marshall, father of Premier Steven Marshall - The Advertiser
item.description:
Tributes for late, respected businessman Tony Marshall, father of Premier Steven Marshall  The Advertiser

Tributes are being paid to the late, respected businessman Tony Marshall — the father of Premier Steven Marshall.

item.title: Former SA premier Jay Weatherill retires (full speech) | ABC News - ABC News
item.description:
Former SA premier Jay Weatherill retires (full speech) | ABC News  ABC News

Jay Weatherill, the former Labor South Australian premier, announces his retirement from state politics. The former lawyer was first elected in 2002 and was directly appointed to premier Mike Rann's cabinet. He replaced Mr Rann as premier in 2011. Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-12-06/former-sa-premier-jay-weatherill-to-retire-from-politics/10588600 For more from ABC News, click here: http://www.abc.net.au/news/ Subscribe to us on YouTube: http://ab.co/1svxLVE You can also like us on Facebook: http://facebook.com/abcnews.au Or follow us on Instagram: http://instagram.com/ab...

item.title: Jay Weatherill quits politics - The Advertiser
item.description:
Jay Weatherill quits politics  The Advertiser

Mr Weatherill chose State Parliament’s final scheduled sitting day of the year to confirm his exit, after 16 years of service, which will trigger a by-election in his safe western suburbs seat of Cheltenham. Flanked by his wife and two daughters in a press conference yesterday, Mr Weatherill said he would devote himself to family life and had no plans for the next phase in his career. Mr Weatherill said he was proud of how the State Government under his leadership handled the fallout from the shelving of the Olympic Dam expansion and announcement that Holden’s Elizabeth factory would close ...

item.title: SA Liberal MPs cross the floor to oppose controversial mining bill - ABC News
item.description:
SA Liberal MPs cross the floor to oppose controversial mining bill  ABC News

A rebel Liberal MP "had no choice" but to cross the floor over debate on a contentious mining bill in South Australia's Parliament, leading to him being labelled as "destructive" and a "bloody fool". Key points: - Four SA Liberal MPs vote against debate on amendments to the Mining Act - They want farmers to be able to 'veto' mining exploration on their land - Labor says it's a sign of the disunity in the State Government South East MP Nick McBride, along with fellow Liberals Fraser Ellis, Dan Cregan and Steve Murray, yesterday sided with Labor on three consecutive votes to postpone debate o...

item.title: Andrews leads in staffing surge - The Australian
item.description:
Andrews leads in staffing surge  The Australian

Victoria’s Labor government has overseen the most extravagant ­rise in taxpayer-funded political staff, with numbers swelling by more than 100 per cent in six years, as state and federal governments increasingly shun public servants in favour of highly paid advisers. The total number of state and federal ministerial advisers — who typically earn between $130,000 and $250,000 a year — increased by 13 per cent to 1666 over the six years to 2018, or more than 30 per cent faster than the rate of ­population growth over the same period. The analysis by The Australian and freelance legal writer S...

item.title: Labor's battery subsidy plan could 'tip the market' for household batteries - ABC News
item.description:
Labor's battery subsidy plan could 'tip the market' for household batteries  ABC News

Battery company Sonnen says federal Labor's plan to introduce battery subsidies could "tip the market" for household batteries and propel it into the same sphere as household solar systems. Key points: - SA battery scheme took effect last month and provides subsidies of up to $6,000 - Federal Labor Party announced a similar policy, promising subsidies of up to $2,000 - Battery company said two subsidies could be a game-changer for Australia's battery industry The German company is expected to begin manufacturing household battery systems in the next few weeks at the former Holden factory in...

item.title: Govt again promises new WCH — 1334 days later - The Advertiser
item.description:
Govt again promises new WCH — 1334 days later  The Advertiser

Tuesday’s announcement — 1334 days after Premier Jay Weatherill’s original $600 million pledge — has been slammed by the Opposition as “more political fantasy by a Government addicted to re-announcements”. The new hospital is Treasurer Tom Koutsantonis’ final health splurge before Thursday’s State Budget, as foreshadowed in Tuesday’s Advertiser. Transforming Health explained Opposition health spokesman Stephen Wade said the public should not rush to believe the Government’s promises. “Forty three months later there are no plans, no expressions of interest, no money in the forward budgets an...

item.title: Ca$hing in on final$ - The Advertiser
item.description:
Ca$hing in on final$  The Advertiser

THIS week Off The Record checks the financial scoreboard for the AFL’s Adelaide finals, finds a controversial massage MP rubbing shoulders with local Liberals and reveals a health chief’s painful slip-up at – or not quite at – the new RAH. Ca$hing in on final$ A TIMELY windfall approaching $500,000 will land in Adelaide Oval’s coffers as a result of hosting an unprecedented three AFL finals this month. But the really big cash will go to the AFL, which paid only $5 million towards the taxpayer-funded $535 million Oval upgrade. The Adelaide Crows and Port Adelaide will both host finals, on Th...

item.title: Jay’s nay on right-wing remark - The Australian
item.description:
Jay’s nay on right-wing remark  The Australian

Mr Weatherill, who refused to comment last week on the report on pro-green website Renew Economy, yesterday spoke publicly about his alleged remarks. Asked by The Australian if he believed calling his critics “right-wing f..kwits” was appropriate, Mr Weatherill said: “It was just some light-hearted remarks. “I think I was misheard. I think I said right-wing sceptic and there was a bit of background noise. It was a private function. It was a light-hearted remark. The person they were directed at doesn’t seem to have taken any offence.” Speaking at the launch of federal Labor MP Mark Butler’s...

item.title: Aussie ploy for $420 billion space industry - The Advertiser
item.description:
Aussie ploy for $420 billion space industry  The Advertiser

The two states signed a memorandum of understanding on Monday in Canberra to work towards a national agency, with SA Premier Jay Weatherill saying it is critical Australia takes a bigger part in the international space industry for the economic benefits. “The space sector has enormous growth potential and is a perfect fit for South Australia, given our national leadership in other high-tech industries,” Mr Weatherill said. “The space sector will provide opportunities for traditional manufacturers to transition to a high-tech, high-growth sector.” Australia is one of only a few developed cou...

item.title: Australia welcomes space centre in Adelaide - The Australian
item.description:
Australia welcomes space centre in Adelaide  The Australian

SA Premier Jay Weatherill says Australia's first space centre will create more high-tech jobs.

item.title: Adelaide gets world’s largest revolving platform - The Advertiser
item.description:
Adelaide gets world’s largest revolving platform  The Advertiser

Centre’s $397 million East Building. Featuring two 18-metre revolving drums which can hold up to 320 people each, the building will be able to be reconfigured for events, conferences and concerts within minutes. South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill said the project is “forecast to inject an additional $1.92 billion into the state’s economy over the next 25 years”. “It’s already helped create hundreds of jobs during the construction phase — and will continue to create even more in our visitor economy,” he said. Already, the State Government’s Convention Bid Fund has secured conventions wo...

item.title: Vote for your favourite community projects - The Advertiser
item.description:
Vote for your favourite community projects  The Advertiser

The $40 million Fund My Neighbourhood program was launched by Premier Jay Weatherill this morning. South Australians can nominate projects valued between $10,000 and $150,000 to improve their neighbourhood or bring their communities together, and then vote for their favourites. Mr Weatherill said Fund My Neighbourhood was “one of the world’s biggest participatory budgeting exercises”. A total of $20 million has been allocated across the state for round one of the program. A further $20 million will be available in round two next year. “Nobody knows your neighbourhood better than you,” Mr We...

item.title: New watchdog for election costings - The Advertiser
item.description:
New watchdog for election costings  The Advertiser

The Advertiser can reveal the Parliamentary Budget Advisory Service, which was required in the agreement between independent minister Geoff Brock and Premier Jay Weatherill to deliver minority government in 2014, will soon start operation and cost taxpayers $1.7 million. It is similar to the Parliamentary Budget Office in Canberra and will be open to use by all parties with seats in State Parliament, including the Opposition and Nick Xenophon Team. Once the election is officially called, the service will also be made available to the leaders of registered political parties without represent...

item.title: All systems go for SA space businesses - ABC News
item.description:
All systems go for SA space businesses  ABC News

The South Australian Government says it wants to capitalise on the fast-growing multi-billion dollar business around space, announcing the creation of a South Australian Space Industry Centre. The Government said the centre (SASIC) would help to fuel space industry innovation, encourage start-ups and create high-tech jobs. The announcement comes ahead of the International Astronautical Congress which is being held in Adelaide next week, with some of the largest space agencies and companies — including NASA and SpaceX — to be in attendance. "We know that the space industry in this country an...

item.title: Staffer’s luxury flight to China - The Australian
item.description:
Staffer’s luxury flight to China  The Australian

The trip by Gemma Paech, a research officer to Labor MP Chris Picton, saw her spend $4907.51 on business-class airfares from Adelaide to Brisbane, Hong Kong, Beijing and Sydney. Ms Paech accompanied Mr Picton, the Assistant Minister to the Treasurer, on the trip from June 5-9 to attend boutique renewable­ energy forum Under2 Clean Energy and “promote South Australia’s credentials as a leading proponent of the low-carbon­ transition”. In his maiden speech to parliament in 2014, Mr Picton praised his “friend” Ms Paech for her work on his election campaign. Ms Paech and Mr Picton had special b...

item.title: Whyalla steelmaking business Arrium to be sold to British company - ABC News
item.description:
Whyalla steelmaking business Arrium to be sold to British company  ABC News

Steelmaking business Arrium is to be sold to a British company and not the Korean consortium identified as the preferred bidder, SA Premier Jay Weatherill has confirmed. The business will be sold to London-based GFG Alliance, formerly known as Liberty House. "The sale of the whole of the business is a dramatic victory for us here in SA," Mr Weatherill said. "Any self-respecting nation needs its own capacity to create steel products. This is about building our nation, it is about building our national infrastructure and we cannot be beholden to other countries steel industries." The sale is ...

item.title: ‘I won’t be lectured by banks’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘I won’t be lectured by banks’  The Australian

The South Australian Premier today said he would “vigorously” pursue his controversial state bank tax despite its expected defeat in the state’s legislative council later this year. “Are we seriously going to be lectured by the banks? The money launderers to organised crime and terrorist groups, are we seriously going to be getting lectures from them?” he said at a renewable energy exhibition in Adelaide. He also accused the banks of “misusing their market power” and used the Commonwealth Bank’s announcement of a net profit this year of $9.9 billion as evidence they could afford it. “We’re ...

item.title: New FMC facilities as Repat readies for closure - The Advertiser
item.description:
New FMC facilities as Repat readies for closure  The Advertiser

The pair today toured new $185 million facilities on the site, which include a 55-bed rehab centre, a 15-bed palliative care facility and 30-bed older person’s mental health unit. Mr Weatherill and Health Minister Peter Malinauskas were joined by senior doctors and nurses from the Repatriation General Hospital and Flinders Medical Centre. The buildings have reached technical completion. Final touches will be added over the next month ahead of services and patients relocating from the Repat later this year. A new 1820-space carpark has already opened, which the Government says will ensure ap...

item.title: ACCC accuses states of price gouging over electricity supply - ABC News
item.description:
ACCC accuses states of price gouging over electricity supply  ABC News

Australia's consumer watchdog is accusing state and territory governments of price gouging when it comes to supplying households with electricity. Key points: - ACCC accuses state governments of price gouging amid energy affordability inquiry - Scott Morrison says states and power companies should count themselves on notice - SA Premier Jay Weatherill says government is out of touch on renewable energy The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission says the states have been focused on making as much money as possible from their energy businesses at the cost of their citizens. Chairman R...

item.title: Olsen to become state Liberal president - The Advertiser
item.description:
Olsen to become state Liberal president  The Advertiser

He is considered the overwhelming favourite to replace party president Steve Murray, who quit on Tuesday to focus on campaigning in Davenport, where he was preselected in March. “I have been asked to stand for the unexpected vacancy. It’s much the same as former MPs Alexander Downer, Rob Lawson, Grant Chapman and so on,” Mr Olsen told The Advertiser. It is expected Mr Olsen, premier from 1996 to 2001, will be elected unopposed when nominations close on June 2. If not, the candidates will face a party state council vote on June 16. Former foreign affairs minister Alexander Downer was Liberal...

item.title: Why Dunstan turned down tilt at being PM - The Advertiser
item.description:
Why Dunstan turned down tilt at being PM  The Advertiser

His former principal private secretary Steven Wright, speaking for the first time, said Dunstan repeatedly turned down key Labor figures, including Gough Whitlam and Jim Cairns, who tried to recruit him federally. “He strongly believed he could achieve far more by remaining in South Australia and leading the country in legislative reform,” Mr Wright said. Dunstan’s biographer, Australian National University historian Professor Angela Woollacott, said Labor stalwart Clyde Cameron offered Dunstan his safe federal seat of Hindmarsh in 1975, but Dunstan again refused. Woollacott said the reason...

item.title: Mobsters, me and the ALP - The Australian
item.description:
Mobsters, me and the ALP  The Australian

Apparently he is asking Vic­torians to believe that even though his office knew who would be attending the dinner at the Lobster Cave restaurant, Guy had never been briefed about this. When you are a minister or opposition leader and you are scheduled to attend a dinner or a function, you are always briefed by your staff on who will be there. If your IQ is higher than 50 and you have not been briefed, then you demand to be told what the dinner is about and who will be there. Unless it happens to be a dinner you personally organised with friends, there is always a staff briefing. The leap of...

item.title: Going to war with banks to win an election - The Advertiser
item.description:
Going to war with banks to win an election  The Advertiser

That time is when you’re in the middle of a crisis of governance, with speculation over the future of your chief executive officer, amid revelations that your bank has been either indifferent or negligent in thousands of instances of money laundering, some involving criminal cartels and terror groups. Hot on the heels of the CommInsure scandal, where the bank was accused of stiffing families out of money despite their having legitimate insurance claims, the Commonwealth Bank has been shamed into shelving $16 million in bonuses for its 12 most senior execs. They include its besieged CEO, Ian...

item.title: Bernardi: Marshall must block bank tax now - The Advertiser
item.description:
Bernardi: Marshall must block bank tax now  The Advertiser

The Australian Conservatives’ federal leader said the Sunday Mail/Galaxypoll – which shows most voters do not support Treasurer Tom Koutsantonis’s new revenue raiser – urged Liberal leader Steven Marshall to oppose the “debilitating” measure. The poll found 55 per cent of respondents opposed the tax on the four major banks and Macquarie Group, almost double the 28 per cent who supported it. The remaining 17 per cent of respondents were undecided. Mr Marshall would not be drawn on the surprise poll result ahead of tomorrow’s Liberal party-room meeting, where MPs will determine whether they i...

item.title: More than 500 people travel to SA's far north for Yami Lester's funeral - ABC News
item.description:
More than 500 people travel to SA's far north for Yami Lester's funeral  ABC News

Aboriginal elder, activist and leader, Yami Lester, has been laid to rest on the red soil of his homeland in front of hundreds of loved ones. In what could be one of the most remote state funerals, more than 500 people travelled to Walatina Station in South Australia's far north to say a final farewell. Lester was described during the emotional service as a proud Yankunytjatjara man who lived a life filled with not only achievement but also hardship and courage. Anti-nuclear campaigner Dave Sweeney said many non-Indigenous people turned to the story of Yami Lester for hope. "We owe him a gr...

item.title: SA to get two new power stations, Premier says - ABC News
item.description:
SA to get two new power stations, Premier says  ABC News

South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill has announced plans for two new power stations. The hybrid turbines will initially be installed at two locations, the Adelaide desalination plant site in Lonsdale and the General Motors Holden site in Elizabeth. They will operate on diesel fuel over the next two summers before being relocated and switched to gas, the Government said. The Government has bought nine new GE TM25000 aero derivative turbines through APR Energy. They will provide up to 276 megawatts of generation to the grid when required. The state-owned generators will be tested monthly a...

item.title: Press Council reprimands The Advertiser for misleading headline about SA premier Jay Weatherill - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Press Council reprimands The Advertiser for misleading headline about SA premier Jay Weatherill  mUmBRELLA*

The Australian Press Council has censured South Australia’s The Advertiser for misleading the public in a story related to SA premier Jay Weatherill and energy minister Josh Frydenberg. Published on 17 March in The Advertiser’s print edition as “BLOWING HIS FUSE: Sparks fly as Premier ambushes minister but exclusive polls reveal SA blames Jay for power crisis” and an online version titled “As Jay Weatherill confronts Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg, poll shows he’s to blame for SA’s power crisis”, the article featured a survey poll from Galaxy Research. Galaxy Research’s survey poll which a...

item.title: Giant leap into space race - The Australian
item.description:
Giant leap into space race  The Australian

South Australia, the ACT and the Northern Territory have signed a five-year agreement to work together to tap into the lion’s share of scientific and economic opportunities expected to flow from an expanded national involvement in the space industry. The global space industry is worth more than $400 billion a year and growing, but Australia’s current share is only 0.8 per cent. NASA’s acting administrator Robert Lightfoot said the move was an excellent opportunity to ­increase collaboration. South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill, ACT Chief Minister Andrew Barr and NT Chief Minister Michae...

item.title: Call an election, Marshall demands - The Advertiser
item.description:
Call an election, Marshall demands  The Advertiser

During a fiery debate in Parliament on Wednesday, Mr Marshall called on Premier Jay Weatherill to “put your money where your mouth is” and trigger an early poll to let voters decide whether the $370 million tax on the nation’s five biggest banks should go ahead. Also during the debate, former Labor-turned-independent MP Frances Bedford refused to vote to endorse the State Government’s Budget. MPs were debating a motion by the Premier commending initiatives in the 2017-18 Budget, which the Opposition argued against. Ms Bedford said she was “unable to support either proposition in its entiret...

item.title: M-word was off the PM’s agenda - The Advertiser
item.description:
M-word was off the PM’s agenda  The Advertiser

But he said nothing about marriage equality — the issue that has dominated national debate for weeks — nor about the escalating tensions between the US and North Korea. Mr Turnbull shared the stage at the SA Liberal Party’s annual general meeting with Defence Industry Minister Christopher Pyne, who threw the Liberals into national turmoil in June after audio leaked of him telling factional allies gay marriage would soon be legalised. The incident reignited debate on the issue, leading to a proposed $122 million postal vote that is already subject to a High Court challenge. But as he preache...

item.title: Arrium steelworks sold to GFG Alliance - The Advertiser
item.description:
Arrium steelworks sold to GFG Alliance  The Advertiser

London-based GFG Alliance (Liberty House) will purchase the Arrium group of companies, although the sale must be ratified by the Foreign Investment Review Board. That is expected to happen by August. Premier Jay Weatherill said the sale was “a great victory for Whyalla and an extraordinary victory for South Australia”.

item.title: ICAC to probe Oakden scandal - The Australian
item.description:
ICAC to probe Oakden scandal  The Australian

Former judge Bruce Lander told a parliamentary committee there had been 11 reports about Oakden from public officers to the Office of Public Integrity, since 2016, with four of those lodged this year. Of those, four matters were assessed as potential corruption and referred to police for further action, six have been classified as misconduct or maladministration and warrant further investigation by his office, and one related to other behaviour. No matters have been dismissed. “One of the most important things is who is responsible for what the chief psychiatrist has found? Nobody seems to ...

item.title: Job loss fears: Voters lash bank tax - The Advertiser
item.description:
Job loss fears: Voters lash bank tax  The Advertiser

The unexpected result will send shockwaves through SA Parliament, as Liberal MPs prepare for a party room meeting on Monday to decide whether to take the dramatic step of blocking the tax. The poll results came amid news of more job losses, as Walker’s Exhaust announced yesterday that it would close its O’Sullivan Beach plant, costing 128 jobs, when Holden closes in October. It will end the company’s 30-year history in the state after attempts to diversify and survive the closure of Australia’s last car manufacturers were unsuccessful. The poll finds 55 per cent of respondents are opposed t...

item.title: Weatherill must come clean - The Australian
item.description:
Weatherill must come clean  The Australian

Batteries are supposed to be the answer to the world’s future energy demands. Perhaps they will be but I suspect that won’t be any time soon. For Musk, there is tremendous upside in his venture in South Australia. If this mega battery can produce real power when it is needed in a state that lives on a knife’s edge of praying that the sun keeps shining and the wind keeps blowing. If the battery works, Musk gets massive global publicity and an enormous boost to being able to sell his batteries all over the world. By the same token, if this new battery provides only 1½ hours of power a day the...

item.title: Family fears Oakden delay - The Australian
item.description:
Family fears Oakden delay  The Australian

South Australian Labor MPs and two independent ministers yesterday used their numbers to vote against a bill to hand Independent Commissioner Against Corruption Bruce Lander the ­discretion to hold misconduct and maladministration hearings in public, angering dozens of people whose family members lived at the now-closed centre. Mr Lander had called for open hearings since October, after ­releasing the findings of his investigation into a land-swap deal at Gillman. He repeated his calls after announcing the Oakden abuse investigation in May. He was unavailable yesterday. Clive Spriggs, whose...

item.title: Treaty, yeah? Not on my watch, says Marshall - The Advertiser
item.description:
Treaty, yeah? Not on my watch, says Marshall  The Advertiser

In a move that will set the tone for how a Liberal Government would handle Aboriginal issues, Mr Marshall sayssymbolism will be scrapped and health, education, jobs and safety prioritised. Speaking to the Sunday Mail during a three-day trip to the APY Lands last week, Mr Marshall said treaties were unworkable and not a priority for Aboriginal communities in South Australia. “Treaties are a cruel hoax because they promise hope but don’t deliver practical outcomes,” he said. “We have been here three days and nobody has raised the issue. The Anangu people want practical solutions and that is w...

item.title: $649m in aged care after Oakden - The Australian
item.description:
$649m in aged care after Oakden  The Australian

Queensland (2680), Victoria (2645), NSW (2470) and Western Australia (1623) will get the lion’s share of the 9911 new places, to be announced today by federal Aged Care Minister Ken Wyatt. The big spending, which includes major capital works for vulnerable dementia ­patients, follows a spate of concerns about aged-care standards. Longstanding and systemic abuse has been uncovered at the Oakden centre and also at the Opal Raymond Terrace Gardens home near Newcastle, NSW, where a resident was found with maggots in her mouth. Australian Aged Care Quality Agency chief executive Nick Ryan has ap...

item.title: Jay’s off to Europe — to score us some jobs - The Advertiser
item.description:
Jay’s off to Europe — to score us some jobs  The Advertiser

Mr Weatherill departs on Friday night for the week-long trip to the United Kingdom, France and Italy. He is expected to hold a series of meetings, including with French Minister for European and Foreign Affairs Jean-Yves Le Drian, representatives from submarine builders Naval Group (formerly DCNS) and Neoen, the French firm building the world’s largest lithium-ion battery with Tesla. Mr Weatherill also plans to meet European business representatives who may invest in South Australian industries including mining, tourism, food and wine, IT and advanced manufacturing. “We’re entering an excit...

item.title: Bligh fears bank levy ‘domino effect’ - The Australian
item.description:
Bligh fears bank levy ‘domino effect’  The Australian

Australian Bankers’ Association chief Anna Bligh conceded the banks had to do more to win public support but went on the attack against the state levies and the federal Labor plan to hold a royal commission into the industry. Ms Bligh, a former Queensland Labor premier, turned her sights on Labor governments in South Australia and Western Australia for planning or considering state levies that copy the shock federal impost unveiled in the May budget. South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill has vowed to impose the state levy but his proposal is heading for defeat in the upper house, raising ...

item.title: ‘Mega battery not the solution’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘Mega battery not the solution’  The Australian

But the acting prime minister said people shouldn’t think this is going to be the power solution for the state. “It’s a good idea but the capacity is not there,” Mr Joyce told ABC TV on Sunday. “You know, a grain of sugar is an advantage to a teaspoon, but it doesn’t make a hell of a lot of difference.” He cautioned against thinking “coal-fired power is an evil word” and lauded his government’s plan to build larger storage capacity through expanding the Snowy Hydro scheme. South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill, who went to see the site for the battery on Sunday, described the federal reac...

item.title: Weatherill takes his spin to new level - The Advertiser
item.description:
Weatherill takes his spin to new level  The Advertiser

Premier Jay Weatherill has cleared the Cabinet decks, and he is in the process of attempting to defuse other issues which could be negatives for both him and Labor. The opening of the nRAH was good news, despite new Health Minister Peter Malinauskas discovering concerns from nurses “a little bit alarming” during his first tour. They will be dealt with, and the government can continue to enjoy relative pride in its accomplishment. But that may not be sufficient next March to convince a majority of voters to re-elect the government. The decision to sack the government’s preferred developer fo...

item.title: ‘Levy your own bank tax’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘Levy your own bank tax’  The Australian

The Weatherill government seized on the report by The Australia Institute’s senior economist, Matt Grudnoff, in a bid to blunt ­attacks in question time yesterday over its controversial $370 million impost on the major banks. The bank tax, announced without consultation in SA’s budget a fortnight ago, is in serious doubt with the Liberal opposition vowing on Monday to block it in parliament. There is a prospect of the budget bill being rejected outright and a slim chance of an early election. The next poll is due in March. Mr Grudnoff’s paper said the banks were “very capable” of paying the...

item.title: Weatherill: ‘They’ll have you for breakfast’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
Weatherill: ‘They’ll have you for breakfast’  The Advertiser

Mr Weatherill told reporters on Wednesday the Port Augusta community would have the Federal Government “for breakfast” if they didn’t deliver the loan, despite Federal Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg saying the Government hadn’t received an application for SolarReserve’s new project. Mr Frydenberg said announcing the deal before the loan had been approved was “the sort of gamesmanship we’ve come to expect from Jay Weatherill”. “We’re committed to $110 million, we’re waiting on the company to put the paperwork, but as I’ve said repeatedly, it is more than passing strange that both the compan...

item.title: 'Selfless and heroic' Australian nurse Kirsty Boden died while running to help injured on London Bridge, say grieving family - The Telegraph
item.description:
'Selfless and heroic' Australian nurse Kirsty Boden died while running to help injured on London Bridge, say grieving family  The Telegraph

An Australian nurse who has been working in London, Kirsty Boden, 28, has been found dead. Her family said in a statement: “Kirsty was loved and adored by her family, friends and boyfriend. She was the most outgoing, kind and generous person who loved to help people. Helping people was what she loved to do in her job as a nurse and in her daily life. “As she ran towards danger, in an effort to help people on the bridge, Kirsty sadly lost her life. We are so proud of Kirsty’s brave actions which demonstrate how selfless, caring and heroic she was, not only on that night, but throughout all o...

item.title: It pays to be at peace with Canberra - The Advertiser
item.description:
It pays to be at peace with Canberra  The Advertiser

Momentum has firmly swung behind Labor leader Bill Shorten, as a lot of voters seem to prefer a man who brought down two prime ministers not that long ago over a party who did that exact same thing extremely recently. This change, which now seems almost inevitable, would have big impacts at the state level where Premier Steven Marshall is urging battle-weary South Australians to ease back into a relaxed and comfortable life. In the seven months that Mr Marshall has been running the show in SA, he’s reset relations with the Federal Government. Under his predecessor Jay Weatherill, the State ...

item.title: Quentin Kenihan to be honoured with public service - The Advertiser
item.description:
Quentin Kenihan to be honoured with public service  The Advertiser

The beloved Adelaide entertainer and disability advocate passed away on October 7. He was 43. The commemorative service will be jointly hosted by the State Government and City of Adelaide and will honour Kenihan “as a great South Australian who captured the hearts of the nation, overcame significant challenges to live an amazing life”. It will be held at Adelaide Town Hall on Sunday, October 28. Premier Steven Marshall announced the service on Wednesday and paid tribute to “one of South Australia’s favourite sons”. GALLERY: Quentin’s life in pictures “Despite his well-documented health chal...

item.title: Wide reforms inspire sense of confidence - The Advertiser
item.description:
Wide reforms inspire sense of confidence  The Advertiser

On the back of major defence contracts, tax reform and a focus on emerging industries including space, technology and advanced manufacturing, they believe the state is well placed to capitalise on the business community’s renewed sense of optimism. AICD SA/NT division president Roger Sexton said the State Government’s reform agenda was inspiring confidence across the state’s business community. “There is an increasingly buoyant outlook on the state’s economy,” he said. “There is a clear plan from government and we are looking at that translating to directors and businesses having the confid...

item.title: Federal Government fast tracks $395m for key infrastructure projects in South Australia - ABC News
item.description:
Federal Government fast tracks $395m for key infrastructure projects in South Australia  ABC News

Three of South Australia's key infrastructure projects will be completed in the next four years, with the Federal Government today announcing it would fast track almost $400 million of funding. Key points: - Federal Government fast track $395m of funds for infrastructure projects in SA - The three key projects will be completed in the next four years - Deputy Prime Minister says the move is an example of his strong relationship with the State Government With the State Budget set to be handed down this Tuesday, the Federal Government will bring forward earmarked funds of $395 million towards...

item.title: 'Appalling' hypocrisy: Labor cries foul over SA Premier's Kiwi consultant $100,000 payday - ABC News
item.description:
'Appalling' hypocrisy: Labor cries foul over SA Premier's Kiwi consultant $100,000 payday  ABC News

The South Australian Government is spending almost $100,000 of taxpayers' money to bring a New Zealand consultant into Premier Steven Marshall's department for a month's work, in a move the Opposition says shows "appalling" hypocrisy. Key points: - State Government is spending $91,500 in taxpayers' money to bring in a NZ consultant - Wayne Eagleson will spend 30 days advising the public service over a five-month period - Opposition says the move shows "appalling" hypocrisy A contract signed in June will see Wayne Eagleson — chief of staff to former New Zealand prime ministers John Key and B...

item.title: SA Premier pledges $14m boost to accelerate interconnector project - ABC News
item.description:
SA Premier pledges $14m boost to accelerate interconnector project  ABC News

The South Australian Government will spend $14 million in an attempt to accelerate a project to build a new interconnector with New South Wales. Key points: - Premier Steven Marshall announced the policy last October while still in opposition - The project could be completed earlier than the previous 2021-22 goal - The Opposition said it should have gone out to tender to "use the money as wisely as possible" Premier Steven Marshall made the announcement at the Liberal Party's South Australian branch annual general meeting today, spruiking the project as one that would save customers money o...

item.title: 'Steves' match number of women in SA's cabinet - ABC News
item.description:
'Steves' match number of women in SA's cabinet  ABC News

We already know there are more male CEO's named John, Peter and David than there are female CEO's, and in South Australia it's become apparent there are just as many "Steves" as there are women in cabinet. External Link: Nick Harmsen tweet: Liberal MP Vincent Tarzia elected Speaker unopposed. As tradition dictates, he’s dragged to the chair by the Premier and Opposition Leader While the state's new-look parliament is younger and more gender-diverse its proliferation of the namesake was noted during the first day back at Parliament. A total of 47 new and returning Lower House MPs, and 22 new...

item.title: Decade-long fracking ban may not need law change, SA Premier says - ABC News
item.description:
Decade-long fracking ban may not need law change, SA Premier says  ABC News

South Australian Premier Steven Marshall has revealed he is still considering whether to enshrine in law a moratorium on fracking for natural gas in the state's south-east. On a visit to Mount Gambier, Mr Marshall told ABC Radio his cabinet had already implemented the 10-year moratorium by issuing a direction to the public service. "We made it on Monday and I wanted to come straight down here and assure the people of South Australia that we've been true to our word," he said. "We didn't want to wait until Parliament resumed. We've already issued an instruction." But Mr Marshall indicated th...

item.title: Malinauskas signals shift on ICAC secrecy, unveils SA shadow cabinet - ABC News
item.description:
Malinauskas signals shift on ICAC secrecy, unveils SA shadow cabinet  ABC News

South Australia's new Labor leader, Peter Malinauskas, has signalled his party may support legislation to allow open ICAC hearings, a marked shift from the party's policy under former premier Jay Weatherill. Mr Malinauskas revealed his position while unveiling his shadow cabinet line-up. Changes to stance on ICAC signalled Mr Malinauskas said he had called the Independent Commissioner Against Corruption, Bruce Lander, shortly after his election by the ALP caucus yesterday and would meet the commissioner next week to discuss whether he should be granted the right to conduct maladministration...

item.title: To infinity and beyond, says new leader - The Advertiser
item.description:
To infinity and beyond, says new leader  The Advertiser

Premier Marshall has followed his predecessor in taking space and defence industries under his wing. Mr Marshall will give the opening speech on Thursday morning at the Fifth South Australian Space Forum, which will hear from global leaders on the opportunities in orbit and beyond. Former NASA astronaut Pamela Melroy is one of the speakers — she is a former space shuttle commander contemplating a move to Adelaide as the industry skyrockets. Mr Marshall said he would build on SA’s proud history in space. “The SA Government is committed to ensuring this state will be a key and increasingly pr...

item.title: Do you know who this is? Tip — he was one SA’s most powerful man - The Advertiser
item.description:
Do you know who this is? Tip — he was one SA’s most powerful man  The Advertiser

The 72-year-old former premier will be on the water again Tuesday morning, competing in the “super, super veteran’’ category of the Australian Barefoot Waterski Championships which are being held on the Torrens and the Patawalonga until Sunday. Afterwards a clearly happy Mr Olsen said it “was just like every time going barefoot, exhilarating. It’s a great sensation’’. But he said this was the first time he had performed the feat in the middle of the city, as well as the first time he has competed in the national championships. And “no’’, he was not concerned about the quality of the water i...

item.title: Weatherill to resign as leader after SA Labor loss - ABC News
item.description:
Weatherill to resign as leader after SA Labor loss  ABC News

Defeated premier Jay Weatherill says he will resign as Labor leader after losing this weekend's election to the Liberals. Key points: - Jay Weatherill says a new leader will be decided soon - He says he has "zero ambition" to join the Federal Parliament - Steven Marshall says getting the state "back on track" will be his focus Mr Weatherill visited Government House late on Sunday morning to officially resign as premier, where he told reporters he planned to see out his term in State Parliament. "I'm looking forward to that, being the state member for Cheltenham. It's a fascinating seat, it ...

item.title: Jay Weatherill heckled during energy press conference - ABC News
item.description:
Jay Weatherill heckled during energy press conference  ABC News

South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill has been heckled by an environmental protester at his final election campaign press conference — exactly one year after he delivered his now infamous take down of Federal Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg. Mr Weatherill chose to revisit the event in his final campaign pitch, as he unveiled a deal for South Australia to once again build the world's biggest battery, this time at Port Augusta. Mr Weatherill even presented a commemorative mug of the press conference to the householder Geoff Perkins. The pair then watched the key moments on an iPad, with Mr ...

item.title: Political mavericks shake South Australia out of its two-party torpor - CNN
item.description:
Political mavericks shake South Australia out of its two-party torpor  CNN

It was billed as a provincial election, in a part of the country that rarely receives any national attention. But on Saturday, 1.7 million South Australians will vote in what many are describing as the most exciting electoral race in a generation, as maverick insurgents look to overturn the state's traditional two-party political system. In the months before the vote, it was assumed it would be a contest between the ruling state Labor Party, which has held government for the last 16 years, and the Liberal opposition, which famously lost an unlosable election in 2014 when it won the popular ...

item.title: Racetrack and training funding the focus of promises on last campaign weekend - ABC News
item.description:
Racetrack and training funding the focus of promises on last campaign weekend  ABC News

South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill is promising a $100 million funding boost for vocational educational training if the Labor Government is re-elected next Saturday. The bulk of the funding would go towards an estimated additional 18,000 accredited training places. Today Liberal Leader Steven Marshall focused his campaigning on Victoria Park, but he has already promised a $100 million funding boost for training with a pledge to create an additional 20,815 training places and a new technical college in Adelaide's north-western suburbs. Mr Weatherill said Labor's pledge would include a c...

item.title: SA Liberals propose Oakden replacement on Repat site - ABC News
item.description:
SA Liberals propose Oakden replacement on Repat site  ABC News

The SA Liberals have formalised plans to move former residents at the condemned Oakden nursing home to a new facility on the now-closed Repatriation General Hospital at Daw Park in Adelaide's south. Liberal leader Steven Marshall made the $14 million election promise two days after the Independent Commissioner Against Corruption made findings of maladministration against five public servants over the Government's failure to supervise staff at the now-closed facility. The SA Government has already shifted Oakden patients to refurbished accommodation at nearby Northgate, while it searches for...

item.title: The Sally Zou Code: What her $1.2m cheque really signifies - The Advertiser
item.description:
The Sally Zou Code: What her $1.2m cheque really signifies  The Advertiser

Ms Zou last week tweeted an image of a cheque for $1.2 million, made out to the South Australian Liberal Party, along with a cryptic message that included the phrase “Perhaps is casual transmigration, and this was born”. The tweet has since been deleted. But upon closer inspection, the dollar amount of $1,212,018 also represents the date (in American style where the month comes first) 1/21/2018 — or Mr Marshall’s birthday. It hasn’t gone unnoticed by some South Australian politicians. Earlier, Premier Jay Weatherill said Labor would not take a donation of that magnitude from an individual, ...

item.title: North Adelaide to get trams back after 60 years under Labor promise - ABC News
item.description:
North Adelaide to get trams back after 60 years under Labor promise  ABC News

SA Labor has unveiled another major public transport election promise, committing to extend the tramline along O'Connell Street into North Adelaide if re-elected next month. The pledge for the $259 million first stage of the ProspectLink extension follows yesterday's announcement of a $279 million tram extension into Norwood, into the heart of Liberal leader Steven Marshall's electorate. A new way to stay across the SA election ABC News on Messenger can tell you about all the big moments from the campaign trail. Tap to find out more. That announcement drew a major distinction between the tw...

item.title: Jay has some cause for smile - The Advertiser
item.description:
Jay has some cause for smile  The Advertiser

Premier Jay Weatherill is Ladbrokes’ new tip to win the election and secure Labor a fifth term in power. Mr Weatherill is currently the $2.20 favourite, leading Nick Xenophon’s SA Best ($2.70) and Steven Marshall’s Liberal Party ($3). It’s a marked shift from just three weeks ago, where Mr Weatherill was the $3.60 underdog. The Premier is slightly longer odds with Sportsbet ($2.25) and TAB ($2.30), but is still favourite with all three bookmakers. Both Ladbrokes and Sportsbet also agree that Nick Xenophon’s SA Best is likely to win enough seats to prevent either major party from governing i...

item.title: SA Premier says 'aye' to state tartan - ABC News
item.description:
SA Premier says 'aye' to state tartan  ABC News

While some governments might try to sneak in controversial legislation before going into caretaker mode, the South Australian government made a rather colourful decision in the last hours of its rule before the upcoming election. Premier Jay Weatherill quietly said 'aye' to a pre-election policy to officially adopt a South Australian tartan. External Link: Nick Harmsen tweet What does the new tartan represent? Lodged officially with The Scottish Register of Tartans in February, South Australia's new material features five colours. - Red represents the Sturt Desert Pea - Black is for the Pip...

item.title: Why you should care about what happens in the SA election - ABC News
item.description:
Why you should care about what happens in the SA election  ABC News

The writs have been issued, and the South Australian election is officially on. And it's going to be a very interesting campaign in the lead up to March 17. Here's why you should care. South Australia's current Premier has no issue with causing a stir It may have been a year ago, but people are still talking about Premier Jay Weatherill's spray at Federal Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg. Back then it was described as "unhinged" by some — including Opposition Leader Steven Marshall — but many viewed it as Mr Weatherill's key moment of the year. Relive it now: Video: Watch South Australia's P...
